description: 1570, "a game played with a large, inflated leather ball" (possibly via Middle French ballon) from Italian pallone (“large ball”) from palla (“ball”), from Lombardic *palla. The Northern Italian form, balla (“ball shaped bundle”), today a doublet, likely derived from Old French balle, from Frankish *balla (“ball”), and may have influenced the spelling of this word. Both Germanic words are from Proto-Germanic *ballô (“ball”), *balluz, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰoln- (“bubble”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to blow, swell, inflate”). Akin to Old High German ballo, bal (“ball”), (German Ballen (“bale”); Ball "ball"). Doublet of ballon. More at ball.

entries.meaning: An inflatable buoyant object, often (but not necessarily) round and flexible.
Such an object as a child’s toy or party decoration.
Such an object designed to transport people or equipment through the air.
(medicine) A sac inserted into part of the body for therapeutic reasons; such as angioplasty.
A speech bubble.
A type of glass cup, sometimes used for brandy.
(architecture) A ball or globe on the top of a pillar, church, etc.
examples: the balloon of St. Paul's Cathedral in London

entries.meaning: (chemistry) A round vessel, usually with a short neck, to hold or receive whatever is distilled; a glass vessel of a spherical form.
(pyrotechnics) A bomb or shell.
(obsolete) A game played with a large inflated ball.
(engraving) The outline enclosing words represented as coming from the mouth of a pictured figure.
(slang) A woman's breast.
(slang) A small container for illicit drugs made from a condom or the finger of a latex glove, etc.
examples: And all I had to do in return was take a drive up to Ricardo's place on the way home and then a pretty edgy one back to Rondebosch with a balloon of coke sandwiched between two pairs of underpants.

entries.meaning: (finance) Synonym of balloon payment
examples: The purpose of the balloon is to reduce the periodic payment required during the life of the financing period.

verbs.description: balloon (third-person singular simple present balloons, present participle ballooning, simple past and past participle ballooned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To increase or expand rapidly.
examples: His stomach ballooned from eating such a large meal.
Prices will balloon if we don't act quickly.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go up or voyage in a balloon.
(transitive) To take up in, or as if in, a balloon.
(transitive) To inflate like a balloon.
examples: A puff of wind from the open door caught and ballooned the scanties; off they sailed, out the window billowing into freedom.

entries.meaning: (transitive, sports) To strike (a ball) so that it flies high in the air.
examples: After four minutes, leading goalscorer Haworth slid in but ballooned the ball over from six yards, and Hume then outran the defence to get to the by-line, but he could only hit his cross straight out.

entries.meaning: (aviation) Of an aircraft: to plunge alternately up and down.
